I have a 30+ lb bag of apples from our apple tree that NEED to get used up so I took a chance and QUADRUPLED this recipe (praying for good results...otherwise I huge waste of ingrediants). My only change - I used a more apples than called for (6-7 apples X 4).  My prayers have been answered!! My apples and effort have not gone to waste! I now have an economical recipe for applesauce that tastes wonderful and EVERYONE loves! Thanks a million phatcat! I'll be sure to repeat this recipe every fall!!

country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe!!! I think the type of apple you use will determine how much sugar you need. I doubled the apples and per the recommendation of the local produce manager, I used 3 empire and 5 macintosh. Since these are naturally sweeter than pie apples, I cut the sugar in half, using 1/4 cup for the doubled recipe. I also cut the cinnamon, since I only like a hint of it. Since a few reviewers talked about it being watery, I let it simmer for about 45 minutes. Once it seemed thick enough for my liking, I used the potato masher to make it smooth. Very easy and tasty recipe. You will have to adjust the sugar according to the apples and your personal preference. With the apples I used and cutting the sugar, we took a vote. Two thought the sweetness was just right and three thought it was a little sweet. However, everyone enjoyed it.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I have my grandbaby visiting this weekend from Minneapolis and wanted to make him some homemade applesauce. (I didn't even do that for my OWN kids!)  So I chose this recipe, but only as a reference.  Because it was for an infant not quite six months old I knew I would add no sugar or cinnamon.  But I'll tell you, even if I wanted to, there'd be no way I'd add this much sugar (a tablespoon per apple?) no matter what size the apples were. Also, knowing apples give off a lot of liquid, 3/4 cup of water seemed a lot.  I cut that back to 1/2 cup, and could have used even less - I think 1/4 cup would have been fine.   But that's 2/3 less than the recipe calls for!  I chunked rather than chopped the apples, so I could do a good fork test on a chunk of apple to make sure it was cooked until tender. Again, because this was intended for a baby, I ran it through the food processor (blender would have worked fine too) rather than mashing it. So two stars as written because of the overload of both sugar and water, even tho' it ended up pure and delicious.  I can't wait to see how little Andrew likes it!

text:
This is one of the first things I've tried to cook, and I don't think it came out how it was supposed to, but I think the next time I make it, it will be even more wonderful!! I used 4 small gala apples and 1 medium granny smith, added a little bit more water, and kept the peels on for added nutritional benefit. Next time I will peel them and chop up the peels into much smaller bits and add 'em in...I'll also probably cook it a few minutes longer, I think I probably let it sit on the stove for about 21-22 minutes, stirring occasionally but a few more minutes would of probably been better. I also didn't use an exact measurement on the 1/2 t of cinn. (Just kinda eye-balled it with a 1 t) and it was the perfect amount. I will probably use a tad less sugar too. 
Anyway... all my non-skills at cooking aside, this tastes SOOOOO good!!!! Thanks phatcat for making one of my first cooking experiences a positive one!

text:
Sooo easy and delicious.  I used Jonagold apples and omitted the sugar but it still tasted sweet.  I tripled the recipe and canned the applesauce - don't let the applesauce cool, mash it while hot and pour into hot, sterilized jars, then 15 minutes in hot water bath for pint-sized jars or 20 minutes for larger jars.  It took approx. 2 and 1/2 large apples to fill 1 pint-sized jar. I plan to make more and give them to the neighbors!

I made this but used brown sugar instead. Bring the water and brown sugar to a boil to dissolve the brown sugar before you add the apples. I also added 1/2 tsp of nutmeg and vanilla. For the adults, try an ounce of your favorite liquor, I like amaretto or frangelico.

country:
None
text:
AMAZING!  I've never had homemade applesauce, and I won't be going back to the store bought.  I made a triple batch and used 12 apples - 6 fuji, 3 granny smith, and 3 brayburn.  I used the apples, 1/2 cup water and 2 teaspoons of cinnamon.  No sugar.  I cooked them in the crockpot for 4 hours on high.  A slight mash with a potato masher and they were perfect.  A word of warning: don't try this warm! I had my first taste when the applesauce was still warm and it was kinda nasty.  I was really disappointed until I tried the cold applesauce the next day.  HUGE difference!  I'm on my third triple batch in three weeks, and I'm going to make two more batches this weekend and freeze it all.

text:
Delicious!  I doubled the recipe and brought it on a ladies' weekend trip; they raved about it.  I made this recipe using 1/2 macintosh apples(sweet) and 1/2 granny smith apples(sour).  I only put in 3/4 of the amount of sugar requested in the recipe (this was just the right amount). The cinnamon makes the applesauce look a little darker than in the photo, so put in a smaller amount or sprinkle on top like the photo shows. I used my apple-peeler-corer and I did not have to mash.

photo:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I use this recipe regularly- really easy recipe for a potluck, brunch, or just to have as a snack. I ALWAYS make this in my smaller crock pot, 5 apples always fills it up to the very top, but since they cook down quite a bit, there's plenty of room by the end of 3-4 hours.   A word from the wise, all apples are not created equally! Some apple varieties will NOT mash very well. Gala works well, Fuji does not (if memory serves). You do not need to add sugar to this recipe, which makes it great for diabetics. If you stir gently halfway through cooking but leave the apples mostly intact, it is a great ice cream topping.

text:
This is sooooo good.  Made 2.5 times the original amount, and I just ate way too much in one sitting.
It's such a pain to peel all those apples, and I feel like you lose a lot of good apple, so I just cored them, cut them in quarters, and cooked them that way.  Once it cooled, I used my hands to squeeze the peels away from the apples.  That worked pretty well.

this was so easy and SO YUMMY!

text:
This applesauce was really tasty and different at the same time. Usually when I make applesauce I have this really nice, thickened sauce made when the sugars and water combine. I found that with this recipie though, the water slightly thickened. Don't get me wrong, as I did enjoy it! There are a lot of ways to make the same thing and change isn't a bad thing! This applesauce was all in all, easy, simple, and quite delicious. 
Tip: I added 1/2 a tablespoon of maple syrup (being a true Canadian) and it was da Bomb!

text:
I scaled up this recipe and found that there was way too much moisture.  I ended up taking the apples out of the water and mashing them separately, adding back in a spoonful of the apple water, as needed, to get the consistency I wanted.  I also felt this was a tad on the sweet side, but still really good and likely something kids will enjoy a lot with the sweetness.

This is DELICIOUS applesauce! It is tasty, with just the right amount of cinnamon. I made the following alterations: 1) I only used a pinch or two of sugar, and am glad I did because he natural sugars of the apples made it just sweet enough. 2) I didn't use as much water as the recipe calls for. I'm glad I did because it was hard enough to drain as it was (I used half the water it calls for). I would've given it 5 stars, except for the water problem.

text:
Weeee!  I needed applesauce for another recipe.  Had lots of apples that were on the verge of going bad, so I thought...hmmm...bad apples...need applesauce...voila!  This was super easy.  I put everything into the crockpot and set it on high for about 3 hours.  All I had to do after that was stir it a little bit to break up the chunks to make it a sauce, then I let it continue to cook in the crockpot for another hour with the lid half off to cook off some of the extra water.  Thanks!

text:
We would give this more stars if possible.  My son & husband love applesauce but they really LOVE this version!!!  We try not to use sweeteners so left out the sugar all together - just apples, water & cinnamon.  Took advice of another reviewer and dumped everything in crockpot and cooked for 2-3 hours.  AMAZING!!  They loved it hot, they loved it chilled.  They even loved it when I thawed some frozen raspberries, mushed them and added into the applesauce.  Next time I'll try tossing in a bag of frozen raspberries, blueberries or peaches in the crockpot as well for a flavored variety.  Thanks for such a great recipe!!!

Maybe it would work better if you cook the apples and water without the spices, then drain the water, then add spices.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677172.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I use this recipe when I bake my quickbreads (where I use a 1:1 ratio of oil and applesauce). I substitute Splenda (or generic) for the sugar. Sometimes I'll add an additional fruit (pears and plums are particular favorites). I don't add the cinnamon because some recipes just don't call for it (when a recipes does, I simply add it to the dry ingredients). I puree the resulting product in my blender. My breads come out moist, light and very flavorful. My family loves them and they make great gifts.

text:
Really good, really simple.  I used honey crisp apples so I cut down the sugar a little and I cooked in the crock pot so I didn't have to touch it.  I tried it on low at first but after 4 hours, it was still crunchy so I cranked it up to high for another 2 hours.  I probably shouldn't have gone so long but I had to leave the house so I wasn't watching it.  Next time, I think 3 - 4 hours on high or 6 hours on low.  Also, since I did in the crock pot, I didn't need as much water.  I think I used about half a cup and still had too much.

country:
None
text:
I like my applesauce chunky, so I always make it at home, using a variety of apples like this - definitely with a MacIntosh unless they look bad in the store. I rarely add water - maybe a tablespoon - and never sugar. If the apples seem to need sugar for flavor, I use a little lemon juice. I also microwave rather than cooking on the stove - no scorching, although you have to watch so they don't overflow. My family likes a whole cinnamon stick cooked with it, not just ground cinnamon. Main complaint with this recipe is the unnecessary amount of sugar.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this last weekend according to the recipe, to go with some pork chops and potato pancakes. Loved it, and I'm making it again right now!

I'm using Cortland apples. This time, I doubled the recipe and I also added a half bag of frozen cranberries that I had in the freezer. I started by bringing the cranberries to a boil with the water and sugar, then blended the berries a bit with a stick blender. I chopped all but two of the apples (and kept them in strainer in a bowl of cold water until I was ready to add them because they take me forever to chop and I don't want them browning). I let those cook a bit while I chopped the other two apples, then blended what was in the pot with the stick blender before adding the remaining apples so it'll be just a little bit chunky. 

Just tasted some and it's delicious! Looking forward to eating this all week, and I can't wait to do something creative with the next batch.

This is a great, great recipe! text:
As a child, my mother made the best applesauce.  I remember her squeezing the cooked apples through a colander.  It was so much work and a big mess.  This recipe is the BEST!!!  So easy and extremely tasty!  I used Granny Smith apples, apple pie spice in place of cinnamon, and cooked 30 minutes to let the water reduce more (after it started boiling, I reduced heat slightly and uncovered). Kept the apples in the pan and used a hand blender. One pot cooking!

Display Name:
Lindsay Vereschagin Tripp

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2938722.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great starting point for homemade applesauce. Remember to taste your apples before starting and adjust accordingly, sweeter apples need less sugar and you can always add sugar while cooking if needed. I have used apple juice in place of water a few times but as the juice is sweet I cut back on the sugar when doing so. Play with the spices depending on what you like, cinnamon, nutmeg, ginger (fresh works best but you can add ground ginger), cloves etc. For a special treat for kids you can dissolve red hots (the candy) in the water and add in your apples. This turns them a red/pink color and gives a cinnamon flavor for a fun treat. Like I said this recipe is a great starting point!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/829076.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good and simple recipe.  I did mine in the crock pot.  I used a mix of cortland, Rome, Jonamac, empire and jonathan apples bc I think the more variety you have the better the flavor.  I DOUBLED the recipe but didn't add quite the full doubled amt of sugar bc I like the flavor of the apples to stand out in front of the sweetness.  I slow cooked them for 1 hr on low but that didn't seem right so I kicked it up to high for an hour and that did the trick.  I then took the lid off hit the apples with a potato masher and let it cook for another hour uncovered so it wouldn't be quite so watery.  Came out great!  Not too sweet with a tasty hint of cinnamon.  Will def make again but I think I will just cook it 2-2.5 hours on high with the lid off the 2nd hour, the first hour on low was prob unnecessary.

text:
I used twice as many apples with the specified amounts of water, sugar and cinnamon. I would imagine you would end up with a very runny, sickeningly sweet applesauce if you followed the recipe as stated. With that said, the amounts of water and sugar will be largely dependent on the type of apples used. I used a mix of who know's what. We went to the local orchard and my kids mixed various kinds together. My advice: start with reduced amounts of liquid and sugar and adjust as you go.

Review:

dateLastModified:
2015-02-01T16:53:13.763
helpfulCount:
4
userID:
7180949
Display Name:
rainwalkerSK
isPro:
False
followersCount:
9
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2019535.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The amount of sugar and water needed will vary quite a bit depending on the types of apples that you use. I used a mix of Fuji and Gala apples (just using up what was in my fridge) and although I used five apples, a quarter cup of sugar was way too much. I also had quite a bit of liquid in with the apples when I was done cooking it. I also wasn't clear on how to time the cooking time. I started the timer once the liquid in with the apples was bubbling, and then let it simmer for 20 minutes. The apples were soft afterward, but a potato masher wasn't working at all. Dumped it all in a blender, pulsed a couple of times, and got a consistency I'm happy with.

This recipe is a good starting point for someone who wants to make applesauce but doesn't know how, but it should have suggested starting out with a smaller amount of sugar and then increasing to taste.
Review:
Rating:
5

region:

country:
None
text:
This was my first time making applesauce and it was delicious! I doubled the recipe (I had 9 Gala apples starting to soften so I used all of them); however, I only used 1/4 cup white sugar and about 1 tablespoon brown sugar. In addition, I used 1 teaspoon of Epicure's Apple Pie spice - just to add that little extra flavour. I cooked it for about 30-40 minutes (until it reached the desired consistency, and I occasionally stirred the apples as it was cooking). I was never a fan of store bought applesauce but I will definitely be making this again!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

userID:
13959679
Display Name:
Kownz
isPro:
False
followersCount:

8

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4693117.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this in my crock pot and it turned out amazing! I had five apples that were going bad so I decided to test this recipe. I peeled and cut the apples and tossed them in the water in the slow cooker. I added the sugar and cinnamon on top of the apples. I set my slow cooker on low for 4 hours and when I came home from work I mashed the apples with a fork and turned the cooker on high. I continued to mash periodically for a couple more hours and once it was the thickness I liked I unplugged the cooker and let it sit for about an hour before canning. I didn't adjust the sugar or spice amount to account for the extra apple and it still turned out perfect. I filled one 12oz jar and had some left over (which I ate as soon as it was chilled). My friends loved it!

country:
None
text:
This is such an easy and delicious recipe! I have used it both with apples and with pears since the taste is so similar! I used 10 pears(very, very ripe), 3/4 cup water, 1/2 cup sugar, & 1/2 teaspoons of each: cinnamon, nutmeg, and ginger. Slow cooker for 3 1/2 hours. Then get my electric mixer to chop it up the rest of the way, and stick it in the fridge to cool. Love, love, love! Thanks guys!

text:
OH MY. There are no words to describe how good this is. Plus it's super easy to make. I usually add in 1/4 cup of brown sugar for extra depth of flavor and because I like it sweet :) I like to let it cook down until it just starts to stick to the bottom of the pan. It really concentrates all of the flavors, making it even better! You simply MUST try this and see for yourself!

This was wonderful!  I've never had, much less made, homemade applesauce before.  It was quick and easy.  I served it with grilled pork tenderloin and mashed potatoes.  My husband doesn't compliment my cooking often.  This was no exception...or so I thought.  The next day we went to visit his parents. I wish my husband would say it to me, but this was a great feeling too!  I've made this a few time since, and it's always delicious.  Makes good leftovers too!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/715731.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I canned the applesauce, so I make these changes to the recipe... I cut up about 13 apples, whole-no peeling. I quarter them and throw them in a large pot with 1/2 cup of water and 1 1/2 Tsp cinnamon. Cover and cook them until they are broken down. Next I laddle the apples into a food mill that seperates the skins/seeds/stems from the apple. I then laddle the applesauce in to cans and process them for 20 mins in a canner. Super easy and sooooo much bought.

Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:
2011-07-27T10:23:27.913
helpfulCount:
4
userID:
2456837
Display Name:
Cindy
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
2
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614254.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first attempt at making applesauce, and the recipe is very easy. I doubled it to use 8 apples because I wanted to be able to can some to eat later. I started out using a potato masher to squash the apples once they had cooked for about 30 minutes, but it was still too chunky for my preference. So I used my stick blender to smooth it out, and it turned out perfectly in texture. I tasted the applesauce while it was still hot, and it seemed way too tangy to me so I stirred in another 1/2 cup of sugar. Then I put it in the jars, sealed them, and let everything cool. Well, something must have happened during the cooling because now my applesauce is very sweet! I'll definitely leave out that extra 1/2 cup sugar next time. :-)

text:
I never knew applesauce was so delicious until I made it myself! I used Jonathan apples (NOT peeled or cored), filled a 12 quart stockpot, added just a bit of water (half cup?) and just a bit of sugar (half cup?) and sprinkled on the cinnamon. Let it simmer for an hour or two, stirring it down occasionally, then put it through my kitchenaid fruit & veggie strainer, and canned it in a waterbath canner. It's so much better than anything you can buy at the store. YUM.

Display Name:
Maine Cook

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/289903.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this probably 5 or 6 times (now I'm considering buying an apple peeler so I can make it more. When I make it I DON'T ADD SUGAR. I always use gala apples which are sweet enough. I peel and chunk the apples doubling to 8 apples add about 1/2 the amount of water. and the cinnamon. I take a rubber spatula and stir so that the apples are slightly wet with water and coated with cinnamon. I cook them on low in my slow cooker and give them a mash after 3-4 hours and let them cook a little more. This is wonderful. My 'sugarhound' husband didn't miss the sugar. I served this heated over vanilla frozen yogurt last night and it was AMAZING! Don't be afraid to adjust the sugar in this recipe and remember apples are about 85% water so you don't need a lot of water in this recipe. Just give it a quick stir w/ a rubber spatula from time to time to keep the apples moist while they cook down.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3149458.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I don't even like applesauce yet really enjoyed the end product from this recipe.  I gave 4 stars because I needed to tweak a couple of things.  I doubled the recipe but used 12 apples instead of the 8 called for in the doubling.  I used the same amount of water, only 1/4 cup of sugar, 1/2 tsp. cinnamon and 1/4 tsp. nutmeg.  I coarsely chopped the apples, added all ingredients to a big pot, slapped on a lid and let everything cook for 25 minutes.  I stirred once, let it cook another 10 minutes with the lid off to let it boil down some and then used my immersion blender to get it to the right consistency.  I've given jars of this stuff to 3 people and they all swear it is the best applesauce they've ever had.  For reference, I used Red Rome and Golden Delicious apples I picked 1 week before.

text:
I made this tonight, and it was amazing. I followed the recipe exactly except I blended the apples after they were cooked. I used gold and delicious apples, and It came out great! It was the perfect combination of tart and sweetness. I never thought in a million years that I'd make apple sauce. I didn't even know exactly how it was made before today. I was looking for recipes with apples so I could use them before they spoiled.

Update: After I made the bigger batch, I had 1 apple left over. I tried to make apple sauce in a mug the next morning with that one apple by cutting down the recipe and putting it in the microwave. I don't remember how long I put it in there, but I stirred it once a minute. It turned out great too. I didn't blend it that time.

text:
I have been wanting to make applesauce for ages but always thought it too time consuming. But when I actually looked into it I of course realized I was wrong. I also found that there were as many ways to make it as there were recipes. I chose this recipe because it used the simplest of ingredients and in my humble opinion applesauce should be simple. I had about 2 dozen or so apples that needed to find a new purpose so I quadrupled the recipe except for the sugar as I was using my two favorite kinds, Red Delicious and Golden Delicious, which are sweet on their own. I only added a little under 3/4c sugar. Well it turned out perfect! By the time it cooled enough to be jarred my daughters had eaten a quarter of it.
Thanks for the best recipe. Will be making this many times in the future.

I thought this was a very good starting point recipe. I did use a sweeter apple (Fuji), so I cut the sugar down to 2 teaspoons and even still it's a little sweet to me. Also, there was a lot of water left, so I let it boil without the lid on for about 5 more minutes to evaporate some of the water. I made two batches, both sans cinnamon, plain for my husband, and added a half cup of blueberries to mine for extra flavor. Ran them through the food processor when I finished, and they both came out really great.

text:
I have made this over a dozen times since I found this. This is one of my favorite recipes for when extra kids are around. :D  Today we had 6 kids total, I used 10 apples and adjust ingredients... I pull out the apples from the syrupy juice... and only add some of the liquid. Throw it in my food processor, we end up with the absolute best thick applesauce., with no leftovers. Thank you for posting it :D

I used the advice Reviewed on Mar. 8, 2007 by Jules and doubled the recipe and cooked it in my slow cooker for 3-4 hrs. I peeled the apples and tossed them in the cinnamon and sugar and then added them to the slow cooker before cooking. Then I also added a dash of ground cloves just for fun. This recipe is so easy in the slow cooker and the taste is wonderful.

Like others, I wanted to include the peelings for extra nutrition but I also wanted my 9-month old to be able to eat it so I pureed the peels separately and added them to the apples before cooking.  I used 12 apples, 1 1/2 cups water, 1 1/2 tsp cinnamon, 3/4 cup sugar and cooked it all in the slowcooker on high for 4 hours.  It's a little watery and sweet so I'd reduce the water to 1 cup and sugar to 1/2 cup next time.  Still very tasty!

Oh my goodness! This is the BEST applesauce I have ever tasted...seriously! I used Macintosh apples and followed another reviewers suggestion and tossed everything into my slow cooker. It's really easy and yummy. Thanks for posting. I changed it a little bit and it was still really good. Instead of sugar, I used 2 tablespoons of honey and I used more cinnamon which gave it a brownish color. I added 1 tablespoon of lemon zest to it from the beginning. I also mashed the apples as they were being cooked. I brushed inside of hot sandwich buns with butter and filled them with this apple sauce (warm) and took them for my breakfast which were really tasty and fresh. I also baked it for 20 minutes in a tart shell and it turned out really great.

userID:
5304722
Display Name:
Michael Ireland
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We used the unique crab apples that grow on a tree in our neighbors yard.  The tree is quite old, and produces a huge number of very tart smallish apples.  When cooked, the skins are very soft.  This recipe is very simple; when followed to the letter (leaving the skins on), it produced a sauce that was a tad on the lumpy side, so we pureed it in a food processor.  The net result was a *highly* delicious apple *jam*.  We then tried tripling the recipe, but it proved to be *far* too much water, requiring a very long time to boil down.  So when multiplying the recipe, I recommend cutting down on the water substantially.
Review:

text:
Excellent applesauce!  I had some extra apples and found this recipe.  Was very quick to make.  And, the kids I was babysitting really liked it a lot.  Mine tasted and appeared in color closer to the cinnamon applesauce in the store than the one pictured.    Although, it very similar to the store cinnamon applesauce it is actually much better in taste and texture.  The adults liked this also, that do not normally eat applesauce.  Note: Make sure to use a medium pot instead of a small one, as the applesauce will boil over in a smaller pot.  And, the recipe will only make about 5 very small servings, so you might want to make more. Taste good the next day after it is refridgerated to.  Thank you submitter!  Will definitely make again!

text:
I made this earlier today and my husband and I just finished eating the last bit of it!   Really Delicious!   Not too sweet, just right.  I used 6 diced apples instead of 4 since they seemed small to me (3 McIntosh and 3 Gala),  1/2 cup water,  1/4 cup sugar, and 1/4 tsp cinnamon for just a hint of flavor.  I put it all in a small Crockpot (as someone here suggested) and in 3 hours, I had the PERFECT applesauce!!  Super delicious!!  I did not have to use a potato masher since they kind of dissolved on their own.   My only suggestion would be to double or triple the batch!  Thanks  for the great recipe, Phatcat!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have taken to making this applesauce about every week; it's that good and that easy.  Nonetheless, I had troubles making it at first.  Some tips - you have to cook it until the apples are soft (although cooking it for a shorter time makes the applesauce chunkier), and if you have to add more water, add it.  You don't want your apples swimming in your applesauce, obviously, but adding more water makes your applesauce moister, your apples softer, and eventually easier to mash.  Also, some people have suggesting not using Granny Smith apples because they are too tart, but I don't find that to be the case.  Definitely the applesauce has more tang to it, but it's nowhere near as sour as when you eat a Granny Smith apple on its own.  I think watering it down more, though, may dilute the sourness.

Took the advice of others and threw this in the slow cooker. I'm not an applesauce person (I made them to go with latkes for a party) but this is really good. Chopping the apple: next time, I will do three of the apples into smaller pieces and the fourth in larger chunks - the crock pot doesn't break them down as much as I expected. I'd definitely make this again just for myself!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614242.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe.  One thing that makes it MUCH LESS WORK, is to skip peeling and coring your apples - if you have a food mill.  I used apples from my neighbor's tree and off the ground.  I washed them, cut out the bad spots and quartered them.  I filled my Dutch Oven with the apples, added 1 1/2 cups of water and cooked them for about 20 minutes.  Then I ran them through the food mill.  This left me with a nice applesauce with a rosey color.  I also recommend tasting your applesauce before adding sugar.  I used a sweet apple, so only needed a couple spoons of sugar.  The kids LOVE it!!

text:
I needed to make A LOT of this because I wanted to can it for Christmas gifts.  It turned out great!  What I used:
24 Gala apples
4 Cups water
1 1/2 Cups sugar
2 teaspoons cinnamon
sprinkle nutmeg

I put them all in the slow cooker on high and it took about 4 hours.  It was a bit too watery during the cooking process so I used a turkey baster to remove some of the liquid.  This made a really great apple cider that my kids loved!  I would reduce the water in the future, but got a great cider from it.  Thanks for the recipe! (It ended up making 3 quart sized jars of applesauce for you canners). Thanks again!

text:
SOOO good! It's delicious and so easy. Adding 1 whole vanilla bean or 1/2 tsp vanilla extract makes it so fragrant and taste like apple pie! I used apples I had around, 1 red delicious and 3 Fuji. I kept the peels on, which ads a pretty color, a little crunch and a lot more insoluble fiber. I used a about 1/8 cup sugar figuring I could add more later, and it was perfect. I didn't have cinnamon, so I used pumpkin pie spice. The spice with nutmeg, cloves and cinnamon made it well-rounded. And it smells AMAZING when it's cooking. I'll never buy jarred applesauce again!

I made this today to use up some apples I had in the house. I used 8 apples and a bit less sugar but kept everything else the same. I cooked them longer like other reviewers suggested about 40 minutes and didn't bother mashing them. They were delicious! I really enjoyed eating the applesauce warm. This is a keeper. Thanks for sharing.

text:
Any homemade applesauce is better than commercial stuff, which is all watered down. But try this recipe with less water (you only need a bit, just to keep the apples from sticking, as there's lots of natural water in the apples) and with brown sugar to taste instead of white sugar. Gives a yummy caramel taste.

text:
My family loved this applesauce.  They said it tasted just like apple pie.  I used 16 apples, 3/4 cup of Splenda, 2 tsp cinnamon, 1 tsp nutmeg and 1/2 tsp cardamom.   I was a little concerned that it was too watery, but I just let it simmer longer and it thickened right up.  I never made apple sauce before.  It tasted SO much better then store bought!

text:
This is a great simple applesauce. I doubled the recipe and added the apples and water only, and cooked 20 minutes as directed covered. It looked like way too much liquid, so i cooked it an additional 15 minutes with the lid off. I finally decided to strain off all the liquid and blend with 1/2 cup brown sugar, 1 tsp cinnamon,  and about 1/2 cup reserved liquid. This provided a very smooth applesauce like my family enjoys.

text:
This recipe is 100% perfect. The first time I made it, I doubled the recipe and made it in a pot, and it turned out very well. The second time I added a cinnamon stick (as well as the ground cinnamon), and pressure cooked it for about 6 minutes (8 apples), and that turned out very good as well. I'm making it, once again, but this time with 16 apples. An automagic peeler/corer is so cool, and makes peeling mass amounts of apples a breeze. I definitely recommend this recipe to anyone who likes applesauce :)

I got spoiled on the homemade applesauce that my grandma would always make. Hers seemed to take a lot longer to do so this one is great to have for making it any night of the week. text:
I had leftover apples from stockings so I made one batch with one change. When I cut the apples I left the skin on them - they are the most nutrient-packed part of the apple. The skin becomes so soft they just mold right into the applesauce. Just like the skin of a potato, the skin of an apple is the best part - good for your lungs and brain - preventing cancer and controlling weight. Rethink peeling your apples folks. I also used one less tablespoon of sugar and they were plenty sweet. The sweetness will depend on what kind of apples you use.
Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:

userID:
3851038
Display Name:
Mrs.Mack
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
9
favoritesCount:
50
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Every winter we get a big bag of apples through a fundraiser, and last year I followed this recipe exactly. This is a pretty good recipe to start with, but I agree with the others that it needed less water and sugar than called for (hence one star off). But I think that is partly preference and partly the kind and/or size of apples you use, so some might find this recipe okay as is. Play around with it a bit. 

This year I cut up extra apples (4 medium ones and 2 very small ones), which was about 920g once it was peeled and chopped into 1-2 cm cubes. Since I added extra apple, I kept the water the same (3/4 cup) but still halved the sugar (about 2 Tbsp), intending to add more sugar later after I taste tested it. In the end it didn't need any more sugar since my apples were plenty sweet to begin with. I also don't like a ton of cinnamon in my applesauce, so instead of 1/2 tsp as written (like I did last year), this year I just put in a couple of dashes, which was just right for my taste. 

I cooked it covered on medium heat for about 15 min or a little more, stirring every five min or so. And since I like my applesauce without chunks, I pureed it with an immersion blender. (I pureed it while it was still hot so I could taste test and add sugar if needed, and let it cool after I was done meddling with it.) 

It produced about 3 cups of applesauce.

text:
Since we had a TON of apples from the orchard, we decided to make applesauce and lots of it! We used this recipe as a starting point. Since we wanted to make it as health as possible, we decided to only add half the amount of sugar called and it's still super sweet! We also ended up having to cook for a lot longer than called because there was too much water in it. We ran it through a blender at the very end to make it a little smoother. It tastes wonderful with our few modifications.

Really tasty and super easy recipe! I used 6 apples of various types, and used 1/4 cup and 1 Tbpsn (instead of 1/4 cup and 2 Tbspn called for) to cut down on sugar a bit. Still came out really sweet - next time I might do just under 1/4 cup. Used less cinnamon so that would be more of a background flavor, and threw in a few sprinkles of ground cloves. Came out sweet and flavorful, smells like pie filling. I kind of want to eat all of it immediately.

recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5811464.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been making home-made applesauce for years, both on the stove and in the slow cooker, and I thought I'd share my method.  First of all, the type of apple is very important.  I like to use a mix but they should be sweet apples - Golden Delicious, Gala, etc.  DO NOT USE GRANNY SMITH FOR APPLESAUCE!  No sugar is necessary if you use the right apples.  Don't peel them because the peel has wonderful nutrients - just cut them into chunks.  Next a put a bit of water at the bottom of the pan or crock.  Cook on low in the crock until mushy or on the stove at medium, lid on the pan set askew to let off some steam.  Shake pan from time to time.  Don't let them burn because burnt fruit tastes terrible!  When they are done run them through the food mill - it will take off the skins - and add water, if necessary, for desired consistency.  If you used red apples the sauce will be a pretty pink.  I like to make a whole bunch of applesauce and freeze it in batches - applesauce freezes beautifully!  Good luck!

text:
This recipe can be made even simpler, and healthier--it's plenty sweet without adding any sugar, and you can get away with not even peeling the apples as long as you chop them in fairly small pieces and cook long enough that the skin is soft (unless you have people eating who are very picky about texture). I used 8 small-med. apples and 3/4 cup water was still fine.

userID:
3608218
Display Name:
carolinadewitte
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I, too, used my trusty crock pot to make this. I actually used 5# of apples (from a pick them yourself orchard) and used a mix of Granny Smith's, Pink Ladies and old-fashioned Winesaps. Since the Granny Smith's and the Winesaps are pretty tart, I went ahead and used a 'heavy' cupful of sugar. I also used the juice and zest of one lemon, plus about 1 1/2 tsp of cinnamon. I ALSO add a scant tsp of sea salt. It is important for flavor. The lemon doesn't make it more tart but just rounds out the flavor. I also only used about 1/2 cup of water, as it doesn't boil away in a crock pot. It cooked all afternoon. My kitchen smelled like apple pie the entire time. They cooked down perfectly after about 5 hours, no mashing needed. I froze about 3/4 of this batch in 3 smaller containers. I am going to make another batch very soon, using only Pink Ladies and Winesaps...and I am going to add cinnamon red-hots to this batch for an autumn holiday treat. (I'll cut back on the sugar and won't be using any ground cinnamon. I've done this before and ALL the kids love it. Just don't get carried away in the amount of red-hots you add. They call them that for a reason! I will add about 1/2 TBSP of red-hots per pound of apples. I'll taste it about halfway through, and add more if needed. I will still use the lemon and zest. (We go through a LOT of applesauce, so while the apple season lasts I will probably end up making at LEAST a dozen batches of this size, most to be frozen for the year.

Awesome recipe!  I made this for the first time a couple of months ago, when my husband started getting sick and dehydrated from the vomiting.  The doctor recommended a BRAT diet (bananas, rice, applesauce (!), and toast), and my husband, who is a meat person, wasn't looking forward to it.  I made this recipe, hoping it would lift his spirits.  I added extra cinnamon and 1/2 tsp ginger, to help with his stomach.  He raved about it and felt better almost instantly!  I'm making it again this morning because my husband and son both are feeling under the weather--this time doubling the recipe and using 11 small Red Delicious apples!  Thanks so much!

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Nice guideline recipe, but I found the ratio of apples to liquid way too high as well as sugar. I think it just depends how juicy your apples are and how sweet (I used gravensteins). The sauce was far too watery after cooking covered for the suggested time and had to cook it an extra half hour uncovered to try and reduce it. I ended up adding about 20 more apples to get the consistency right. Also, way too much sugar in this recipe. Taste your apples. Most apples are sweet enough to where you don't need to add so much sugar, if any at all. I cut back the sugar by 1 cup and it was still too much. Applesauce should taste like apples, not sugar. Thankfully adding more apples to fix the consistency also fixed that. I do suggest adding some fresh lemon juice. It really helps perk the flavor.

text:
Had some extra Rome Beauty apples, so I wanted to try to use them in an easy recipe that I have never tried before.  Found this recipe and tried it.  Yummy!  I never thought about trying to make my own apple sauce.  I will never buy store bought again!  I made two batches.  The original was very good.  I like mine sort of chunky, so I was please to have that texture instead of the very fine grain texture of store bought.  The second batch, I added some brown sugar and it was just as good, but just added a different flavor.  If you like apple sauce, try this!  You can adjust this very easily to your taste.  My family has gobbled this up with 24 hours of making it.

text:
Delicious!  And so easy--peeling and chopping the apples are the hardest part.  I used my slow cooker for this and cooked on high for 4 hours.  Since I was using the crockpot, I used less water.  I doubled the recipe and used 1 cup of water instead of 1 1/2 cups.  Although I was worried it wouldn't work, by the end of the 4 hours the apples were soft and easy to mash up.  I love the flavor in this.  This is just personal taste, but I'd prefer a bit less sugar, so I'd do that next time.  I will definitely make this again!  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
Oh my, I didn't know how much of a difference it would make, making applesauce homemade. I wanted something special to serve to my in-laws along with the "Stuffed Kielbasa" also from All Recipes. I loved it and so did everyone else and it was so easy. I made it a day ahead of time in my slow cooker on high for almost 4 hours and then mashed with a potato masher, put it in a pretty bowl with a lid and put in the fridge, and served the next day. So yummy! Good impression on my mother-in-law who always serves fried apples with sausage and sauerkraut.

text:
Since I make mine in the microwave...simply cut the apples(McIntosh, Rome, Jonathan) without peeling and when cool and soft, I put them through a food press.  Simpler than this one,  Just as tasty and healthier since no sugar is added and the vitamins from the peel are still intact.  I don't understand why one needs to add sugar!  I can't review this that highly since making it in the microwave, not adding any extra sugar and leaving the peel is simpler and healthier.  I'm sure this might compare well with a store bought applesauce that has sugar added.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/1747.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Ok I'm changing my review based off of trying both stovetop and slow cooker.  I stand corrected on the stovetop, I even did some research into the Joy of Baking book, the mother of all cookbooks and even it says anything above simmer is too harsh for applesauce.  The stovetop on medium didnt provide super soft apples and browned them a bit on the bottom.  It seemed more like a rush job.  The slow cooker on high for about 2.5 hours instead provided an incredibly soft and beautiful consistency to the applesauce. Using a potato masher, it was a breeze to turn into applesauce.  Also, I halved the sugar and left out the cinnamon.  It tastes way better and more natural that way.  I noticed the applesauces are more dark than storebought but then my husband reminded me that apples turn darker when exposed to air.  Adding anything acid to it to prevent the discoloring, I think, would change the flavor too much.  If you do prefer the stovetop, I'd recommend putting on simmer and triple the time to cook.  It will be so much better!  This is a good recipe, its WAY tastier than storebought.  Also, I was thinking, if you skip the sugar and cinn, this recipe would be perfect for babies starting on solids, just put through a blender before serving :).

This got rave reviews all around.  I was looking for a way to use up some red delicious apples when I stumbled upon this recipe.  I used three red delicious and two gala apples (mine were small apples, so I used one more than the recipe called for).  Since I used a sweeter apple, I cut the sugar down the aprox and 1/8 of a cup.  I used an immersion blender instead of a fork/potato masher to save a little time.  Thanks so much for sharing this recipe!!

I never knew homemade applesauce was so easy!!  This was great!  I wanted to find an applesauce recipe to make for Thanksgiving like my grandmother used to make, so I thought I better try it before Thanksgiving, just in case.  I used my apple/peeler/corer/slicer for the apples, and they were the perfect size.  I doubled the recipe, and per others reviews, added less water and sugar, and then put it in the crockpot on low for 3 hours.  It was delicious!  A definite keeper for our household and a new Thanksgiving tradition!  Thank you very much to everyone!

text:
I had some pears that someone gave us from their backyard and decided to use them instead of apples.  I left out the sugar since they are sweet.  This is delicious!  I peeled the pears and then used my apple peeler/slicer/corer to slice and core them.  Then I chopped them a bit more.  So easy.  I can't wait to try this with apples, too!  My kids and daycare kids all eat unsweetened applesauce, so I will probably leave the sugar out of that, too.  
**I just made this again yesterday with Gala apples and NO sugar and it is wonderful. And I made some with one apple, 3 TBSP water and some cinnamon sprinkled on top in my Pampered Chef micro-steamer in the microwave.  I cooked about 7 min at 50% power and then mashed it up.  This is plenty sweet without any sugar!

text:
This was delicious. I've been itching to make applesauce since June, and I've finally gotten around to making some with the apples from a friend's tree. I used four enormous apples of one kind and one smaller apple of another (though I don't know what type of apples they were) and ended up adding about a cup more water than what was called for. I omitted the sugar because I thought it was sweet enough without it, but then added 3 packets of Splenda to the entire pot. Will definitely make again...it smells and tastes GREAT.

dateLastModified:

helpfulCount:
1
userID:
1969723
Display Name:
KB
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
17
favoritesCount:
64
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674149.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I always substitute apple juice or apple cider for the water to get a richer apple taste.  Also, I add the sugar at the end, so I can taste the sauce and decide how much it needs. I usually use Gala apples, but this time I used Melrose and they were also both tasty and tender for mashing.  You can also microwave everything in a covered glass dish for a quicker sauce.  The time will depend on how much you are making, so check every three minutes or so, until the apples are tender.  Finally, try a serving of apple sauce with a drizzle of cream, or even peanut butter sauce (I just warm peanut butter in the microwave and spoon a bit on.  Both are yummy.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:

Lauren McDonald

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2458998.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the advice of a lot of other reviewers and changed the recipe a bit.  I used 6 apples, half the water and half the sugar in the recipe. I think the amount of water and sugar really depends on the type of apple and how fresh they are. I used Cortland and McIntosh that were picked yesterday (by me), so they still had a lot of water and natural sugar in them. I also cooked them in a slow cooker. It came out great, so I recommend using this recipe as a reference and adjust to your taste.

This was delicious and I will make it again. I may try brown sugar next time. The amount of cinnamon was just right. I cooked it with the lid on for about 15 minutes then removed the lid and cooked it about another 20 minutes to reduce the liquid until it was nice and thick.  My four apples , peeled and chopped, made 4 cups.  When the cooking was done and the applesauce mashed, it had reduced to fill a pint jar ... enough to last me all week. Thanks!

text:
No need to add sugar.  No need at all unless the apples are really tart.  Taste first.

Also, no need to peel and chop apples.  Cook slowly,  cut in 1/2.  Push through sieve or colander to remove the skins and seeds.

Agree with early review that this is a lot of water.  Cook slowly, the apples provide more than enough liquid.

text:
I increased this recipe by 20 times (80 apples). After simmering the apples for about 20 minutes, I mashed them by putting them through a potato ricer. It worked perfectly. Doing it this way also removed much of the water so I added some back to the mashed apples until I had the desired consistency. The best thing was that I had 2 remaining quarts of apple cider which I canned and is now ready to warm at Christmas time and drink around the fire!

I loved this recipe. I only put 1/8 sugar in and added some more water the second time around. The original recipe is wonderful, but I wanted to make it a little on the healthier side and took out some of the sugar added more water and added more cinnamon. Overall the original recipe is delicious is really just depend on how you like your apple sauce (waterym thicker etc....). After making this recipe I will never again buy pre-packaged applesauce again

userID:

Display Name:
CoreyLea
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a very easy recipe. I love when basic ingredients come together to create a delicious dish! I used 5 medium sized McIntosh apples and about 6 small Honeycrisp apples. I used brown sugar, as suggested by many of the reviewers, however, I did not increase the brown sugar to compensate for the increase of the apples (they are both naturally sweet). I did double the cinnamon, and I added 1 tsp of nutmeg, and 2 tsp of vanilla. I also used 1 1/4 cup of water because I increased the apples.

Now for the flavor.....I cannot believe I have been purchasing Motts for YEARS! I do not like applesauce....I buy it for my boyfriend and my 2 boys. This is a HUGE winner!! The flavors are robust, the texture is perfect (Note: I did not use a masher. I used an electric hand blender and only used it to break up some of the apple skins...they did not want a "smooth" texture).

My only reason for subtracting a star is because with me using 11 apples, it did not make a lot. Maybe 4 cups, at best. Sounds like a lot for 3 men in the house, this didn't last more than 30 minutes after it cooled off!!

I will most definitely make this again...but will buy a huge bag of apples from the Farmer's Market instead...and can what we don't eat right away.

Delicious! I've taken a few liberties with the water-to-apple ratio, and I even made a batch in which I used some Granny Smiths, a couple of MacIntosh, a couple of Golden Delicious, and a few Asian Pears, just because it's what I had on hand.

I find myself rarely adding sugar to the recipe though, just some cinnamon, and occasionally ground nutmeg. It really makes it taste like apple pie filling!

text:
This is the first time I've ever made applesauce. The whole family loved it. I followed the recipe exactly, doubled it, and it took me about 30 minutes for my apples to be soft. Then I just threw them all into my vitamix blender and pulsed it a few times. I used gala apples. We put it in the fridge overnight and had it for breakfast. It was perfect. Thanks for the recipe! I will definitely use it again :). If I had anything to add, it would be that after a small bowl of this, I felt a little "sweeted out". At first bite I didn't think it was overly sweet at all but after a whole bowl, I really started tasting the sugar so maybe next time I'll try it with a little less, I'm sure that's just personal preference though :). Good recipe!

text:
First time I ever made apple sauce.  I thought it was simple and perfectly delicious.   I used Cortlandt apples.  Sometimes I've tasted other's homemade apple sauce and thought it was too overdone with spices and lemon and lemon zest and complicated and all the stuff that they said brings out the flavors of the apple.  Except I could hardly taste the apple.  This recipe let me actually taste the natural goodness of the apple.  Just a little cinnamon was a nice complement.  When it comes to good apple sauce, keeping it simple is better!

This is easy done in the crock pot.  Just toss in the apples - we like them chunky - & for extra flavor substitute apple cider for the water. text:
I make a similar applesauce only in the microwave oven.  I use Gravensteins when in season, make 4 or 5 batches
Then divide them into containers and freeze.  Use only 1/2 cup water for cooking in the microwave
And use a large microwave safe bowl, covered.  Cook about 5 minutes, uncover and stir.  If the apples are not 
Done to your desire, cook another minute or two.  I add the cinnamon after the apples are cooked.

text:
This is my third year using this recipe. It's the BEST applesauce recipe - especially for the late summer / early fall when the Paula Red / McIntosh apples come in. (Harder, crunchier apples don't mush up as well as these varieties.) The most time consuming part is peeling the apples. After you've made it a few times, you can 'eyeball' the other measurements (rather than measuring). My kids LOVE this applesauce - especially warm! I make it several times a week while the fresh apples are in season.

None
text:
This recipe was super easy. I took some of the suggestions listed in other reviews. I used 2 granny smith apples, and 2 braeburn apples. I reduced the water to just under 1/4 c (that was still too soupy for me), and sugar to 1/8 c. Next time I will use a pinch of brown sugar as well. I cooked on low for about 25min, and coarsely mashed the apples. I wanted a little thicker still, so I added a little cornstarch as well. Super easy, and my kids loved it!

text:
After a bout with a 24-hour stomach bug yesterday, my 4 1/2 year-old DD needed something bland today, so realizing I was out of jarred applesauce, I made this. I used 4 med/lg Granny Smiths, eyeballed a few pinches of both white/brown sugar and just a pinch of cinnamon. I used 1/4 c apple juice instead of water. At the end of 20 minutes, the apples were perfectly soft, however, I did need to add water in order for my immersion blender to blend to the consistency I wanted, so next time, I would use the recommended amount of water per recipe directions. I enjoyed this (moreso than still-sickly daughter). I would love to simmer this in a crockpot with some extra cinnamon and cloves next time!

text:
This fall a friend with an apple tree was begging people to come take what they wanted, so I helped myself.  I peeled and chopped up all the apples then froze them for later use.  I used one of the frozen bags of apples to make the applesauce.  Of course it took extra time to heat up and simmer, but the results turned out fantastically.  We used our food processor to "mash" the cooked apples because we don't have a potato masher. The consistency was perfect and it took a lot less time than doing it by hand with a fork.  I'll definitely use this recipe again.

The first time I made this recipe as written and found the cinnamon to be overwhelming. I use my immersion blender so there's less clean-up.

country:
None
text:
This is about the easiest fruit there is to freeze.  I have made 8 batches of this recipe so far this season.  I don't even measure the water or the sugar anymore. This is a very simple recipe to adjust the amount of sweetness you want to your applesauce.  I add very little sugar as the apples from our tree are very sweet to start with.  The cooking time of about 20 minutes is correct, even with a big pot of apples.  I've also made this recipe using Red Hots¬Æ to create the cinnamon flavor that my DH and DS so love.  Once the batch has cooled, I store in zippered style baggies so that they lay flat in the freezer.  Thanks PHATCAT for sharing your recipe, it is a winner!

text:
What's great about this recipe is that it gives you a base to work off. I used a ton (maybe 15?) of apples from my apple tree, peeled, cored and sliced with about 1 c. water, 1/2 c. brown sugar and spices to taste (cinnamon, nutmeg, cardamon) and popped it in my slow cooker on low for about 4 hours. Then I mashed it with my potato masher. I will totally be making this again! It's a great recipe with lots of room for alterations and it seems quite forgiving. I had no idea applesauce was this easy to make until I read this!

text:
So yummy and so easy! I never thought to try making applesauce, but I was left with about 8# of apples that were going. I almost doubled the recipe. It's a bit sweet for my taste (I prefer sour) but not much sweeter than conventional applesauce. I cooked on the stove and then transferred into the blender to puree. I'm lazy, LOL. Next time, I will probably cut a little of the sugar OR use granny smith instead of red delicious.

For those of you who want a smooth applesauce, don't transfer it all to the blender at once because there will likely be chunks left in. Transfer in smaller batches.

I went to an apple orchard for the first time and wanted to make as many homemade recipes as I could with the apples. All of the other recipes I found had so many steps and ingredients and took a lot of time. This recipe worked really well for me and was quick! I used roughly 12 apples and tripled everything except the water I only used 1 1/2. I think next time I would only double the sugar as was a little sweet. I only decided to blend it after I mashed it to get more of a smooth store style applesauce and I really loved it! Great recipe!

text:
I love this recipe. When cooking in a slow cooker, however, I usually add at least a couple of fresh squeezes of lemon juice, and I cut down on the sugar. It all boils down to what kind of apples you're using, but the lemon helps it stay fresh-tasting and gives it a little punch, especially if you're making it in large quantities.

None
text:
This was a pretty good recipe. I did change a few things however. I used a couple more apples and less sugar. I can understand that some folks might not like the tartness. I have had store bought apple sauce that was unsweetened and it was quite lovely on it's own. I used a little more cinnamon and I would recommend less water. Bottom line, if you're up for a healthier snack and don't mind a little bit of tartness, use less sugar and let the natural sugar in apples do the trick for this easy and great recipe.

text:
I have to give this one a 5, even though the flavor isn't quite as complex as we're used to. That is easily adjustable--add more of what you like. The method here works like a charm, but I think, personally, that it's too much water. I'd reduce that next time by a bit. I used Gala apples, so didn't need as much sugar as called for. I sliced my apples & didn't bother mashing them; added a couple slices of minced crystallized ginger for a change of pace (we eat homemade applesauce roughly 4x/week!). Thanks, this was a great substitute for the slow cooker version when I was cramped for time!

text:
This is a fine recipe...but why stop at such a small amout? What I do is wash and core the apples, I leave the peelings on, they give the applesauce a nice pink color. I fill up my largest pan with apples and add a little water to cover the bottom and cook until mushy. Then put it through a food mill or seive to get the skins out. Add sugar and spices to taste.

I used Molly Delicious apples.

My family went apple picking yesterday and I picked a bushel of Golden Delicious just for applesauce.  I wanted to make and freeze some.  I decided this was the recipe to use and I am so happy I did.  It turned out so good.  I am still working on more applesauce as we speak.  It was soooo easy to make and not too sweet.  For those that can or freeze, I tripled this recipe and it made about 2-1/2 quarts.  Oh yeah,  I ran mine through a food mill after it cooled down a little.  PERFECT!  Thank you!

I made this applesauce in my slow cooker using double the recipe - the end result was really good.  I did use brown sugar instead of white - and we found it a bit sweet in the end.  I used some tart Lobo apples, so next time, I think I will use less sugar (start with 1/4 cup for 8 apples) and I think I will finish it with lemon juice to give the flavor a bit of depth.

region:

country:

text:
I didn't know homemade applesauce was so easy!  I use an organic produce delivery service and order apples every week with the intention of eating an apple a day, but when I don't they build up pretty quickly.  This is a fantastic, healthy way to use up the excess.  I doubled the recipe, using a variety of apples. Used 1/2 brown and 1/2 white sugar and 1/2 TJs spiced cider and 1/2 water for the liquid.  I had to cook them longer than specified to get them soft enough.  I think next time I'll take another reviewers advice and just let them stew all day in a crock pot.  We had it tonight with pork and I can't wait for it to fully chill so I can eat some more tomorrow.******* UPDATE: MAde this again, but left them for about 5 hours in the slow cooker on high and this was a MUCH better method. SO much easier, and actually tased better too and easier to mix because they cooked more evenly. My only complaint about this is that it doesn't make that much applesauce for as much apples as you put into it, but I think that's the nature of applesauce and not the recipe's fault... This is simply the best applesauce ever.

text:
This is a really good recipe, I only gave it 4 stars because I think it calls for too much water and sugar!  This is my first time making applesauce, though my grandmother made it a lot when I was a kid, so I was craving some this year.I made a huge batch for thanksgiving last night, and some extra for my husband to eat before Thursday.  I used 6 lbs of apples (Macintosh), and about 4-5 cups of water, and 1 3/4 cup of sugar and about 2 tbls of cinnamon.  I used half white and half brown because that was all I had left, I also added nutmeg.    after about 15 minutes of cooking I was able to use my potato masher to mash the apples in the saucepan.  Then I added some whole very thin slices of 1 grannysmith, and let it all cook another 10 minutes or so longer.  I ended up straining out the rest of the water, because I like chunky applesauce like the kind at Chicken out. it was about 2 cups of water.  I have had to threaten my husband with no pie, if he eats all the applesauce before thursday.  It is taking alot of will power to stay out of it.

I followed all of the recipe except I used just under the 1/4 cup of sugar and it was just fine.  In fact in the future I may use even less sugar.  As a lot of people have mentioned, it all depends on which apples you use.  I was sick this week and all I wanted to eat was this applesauce.  Yum! I am so excited to know how to make my own applesauce.  It is very easy and so much better than store bought.

text:
Great, but can be improved upon. I recommend using 1 cup juice of choice (apple, cranberry, pomegranate - my personal favorite) and adding a handful of dried craisins. Then add lemon juice (1-2 Tbsp) and honey or brown sugar to taste after cooking down. I don't peel the apples either. They add wonderful texture (not to mention extra insoluble fiber!).

text:
It's probably fair to say that I prefer sweet applesauce and that's why I am only giving this rating four stars.  I do think this is a great recipe for children because it isn't too sweet. UPDATE: I made this today and now I agree with the rest of the reviews, this is a 5 star recipe.  My modifications were as follows: 5 medium-large granny smith apples, 1/2 cup sugar, a heaping 1/2 tsp. of cinnamon, and a dash of nutmeg.  I also used a box grater to ensure all the apples were relatively the same size.

country:

text:
I have never made actual home-made applesauce before.. This was fantastic! I reviewed several of the comments, and followed their advice at the store, I bought 2 of several different varieties of apples.. I wound up using 5-6 large apples.. Instead of cooking them in a saucepan, I put them in a microwave safe bowl, and nuked them for 7 minutes.. Then I mashed them with a potato masher, and put them back in for another 7, and mashed them again.. This was superb! I had my in-laws over and they all loved it.. Still warm and a bit chunky, nice and sweet! Thanks so much! This is going into my favorites!

text:
I just made this recipe this afternoon, and it turned out very nicely. I used Gala apples, though, and I think next time I'll try it with a different kind of apple, because it was lacking a bit of sweetness/tartness that I like in applesauce.
Very easy, very good. Thanks for posting this recipe!
Update---I've made this recipe several times now. The last time I made it, I didn't put in the suggested amount of cinnamon---I just dumped in as much as I wanted, plus I put in ground cloves. It needs a lot of spice to make the flavour come out. It was the best batch that I've made so far. 
Thanks again for this recipe! :)

text:
My daughter will not eat store bought applesauce but she LOVES this. I used 6 apples, added nutmeg and about a tsp of vanilla. I also only used 2 pinches of sugar, my advice is taste the apples after they've cooked awhile and if they aren't sweet enough then add some sugar. Also 3/4 cup of water isn't too much I used about double that just in case I got distracted, so it wouldn't burn. I just let the extra water boil down but left enough so that when I pureed it, it would be a good consistancy.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/85800.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This looks like good recipe, but it all depends on your personal taste. I did not try the recipe (I have too many apples to count out just 4), but it looks as if there is too much sugar. I would add that amount of sugar to a huge pot, not just 4 apples. Apple sauce is pretty fool proof, you can't really mess it up, it is dependent on personal preference. The longer you cook it the smoother and more "velvety" the texture, shorter cooking with provide a crisper flavor and chunkier sauce. I cook mine in large batches (think 50 gal ice chest filled with apples) in the oven in 2 very large covered pots (even distribution of heat as opposed to stovetop -- decreases burning) stirring every 15-20 minutes. In additon to cooking method, you can also make it with or without skins. A grinder is a must if you choose to leave the skins on. Experiment and have fun.

text:
Very very delicious. I used two Fuji, one Golden Delicious and one Empire for a nice combination. I like my applesauce a bit on the tart side and so added less sugar, and also because the Fuji apples were quite sweet anyway. Peeling and chopping up the apples by hand took a bit longer than I thought, but this was well worth it. The apples cook faster if you chop them finely - oh, and don't forget the cinnamon and a dash of nutmeg too!

text:
This recipe is simple and yet fantastic! I read online that you should use a combination of different apples for applesauce, but I only had Macintosh on hand so I used those - I was definately lucky! Turns out Macintosh is great for applesauce. It was the most delicious applesauce I have ever tried! For the next batch I tried some Gala apples... and it definately didn't match up. I think I'll stick with Macintosh from now on... the tartness really adds to the flavor... maybe next time I'll try a combination with Gravenstein. Sooooo yummy warm.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe probably 100 times now. It is terrific! My family loves it, I love it, and I never buy applesauce anymore. 

Having made it a number of times, I have played with the recipe. Here are my experiences:

I have doubled, tripled, quadrupled the recipe and it comes out great each time. It takes longer to come to a boil, but you cook it the same amount of time. 

Storage--I have found this freezes fairly well, so I often make a large batch. There are some texture changes, so I tend to leave the sauce I freeze a little chunkier so it can be stirred, etc. Let defrost slowly in the refrigerator. 

Cutting down the sugar--I have found this works okay with less sugar, but tastes watery with no sugar. You need a little sugar for the right taste with the cinnamon and to emphasize the apple flavor. The full sugar tastes best. We have also tried this with brown sugar, which gives a little more caramel flavor and deeper color. Use white sugar for the brightest apple flavor. 

Freezing--I have found

text:
WOW!  I use applesauce in place of eggs and oil and this is game changing!  I made it with a big mix of gala, red delicious and granny smith.  I hardly cut them and tossed them in the slow cooker on high.  I added a TON of cinnamon, a splash of water and NO sugar.  Towards the 5-6 hour mark I started checking them, mashing with a wooden spoon.  After 8 or 9 hours I let them cool and put them in the blender with some more cinnamon, vanilla and fresh lime juice to freshen it up.  I have actually been taking it to work to eat, its so delicious and filling! I'm going to have to make more to use in recipes!!

text:
I used 4 apples. Before I mashed them, I felt like there was too much liquid left so I strained most of it out (the sauce would have been too runny), then decided to use the extra liquid for another apple. If I make this recipe again I'll just use 5 apples in the first place, or use less of the other ingredients. So, the ingredient ratio wasn't right for me, but once I fixed that, It came out really good!

text:
I have made this recipe about 4 times so far since July (now Sept) and it hits the spot every time. I do add just a touch more cinnamon per our liking, but it is really good. Even my husband who hates applesauce eats it. One thing that I do change is to put it in the crock pot and double the batch. Set it on high and forget it. I do come back and stir it about once every hour but after 3 hours it is perfectly soft. After that I put it in my nutra bullet and blend the heck out of it. Smooth consistency and well worth the wait.

country:
None
text:
A simple and wonderful recipe that made an awesome first attempt at apple sauce for me. Thank you.  I used gala apples so it took more than 20 minutes for them to cook down.  I also substituted honey for the sugar and it came out great.  I used an immersion blender to make it smooth as I prefer it.  It was a little watery, so I cooked it a bit more.  I quickly found though that I had to leave the lid partially covering the pot, because bubbling smooth apple sauce can fly!  I then just turned off the heat, left it uncovered and stirred occasionally till all the remaining steam dissipated.  Perfection.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a simple recipe that doesn't require a lot of ingredients.  I've made this applesauce quite a few times, using 4 fairly large apples, & a different variety each time, depending on sale prices!  So far I've used Braeburn, Fugi, Pacific Rose, Gala, Jazz, Pink Lady.  Since they're all fairly sweet, I only add about half of the sugar, & used twice the cinnamon, maybe a bit more, depending on personal taste.   When the apples are tender, I mash them with a potato masher & leave a few chucks.  Chill & serve the next day!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4049308.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good recipe for applesauce, but needs some tweaks. I had a ton of apples to use up and found adding extra apples was needed (see second most helpful review). Although I scaled up the recipe, the first result was too sweet--made as written. The second time around, I used just less than half the amount of sugar and it was fine by us. Used a mixture of Macs and Cortland apples, which are sweeter though...so, keep that in mind if you try to make this recipe...with tart apples amount of sugar might be ok; with sweeter apples use less sugar. It also seemed a little soupy to me, but I just let it keep cooking down. Next time I'll use less water. I will make this again for a quick and easy applesauce, with some minor adjustments. Thanks for the recipe!

country:
None
text:
Made this with some modifications.... (1) I did not add much in the way of water because apples are naturally watery and do not require the extra water. I found adding any water at all was unnecessary. Tip- removing the lid from the pot allowed more water to burn off when it got too watery. (2) I reduced the sugar significantly and sweetened to taste once they were cooked down - apples can vary is sweetness though (3) I cooked the apples at a a medium low setting and they cooked for more like an hour. (4) doubled the cinnamon.

text:
AMAZING!! I had a big grocery bag full of apples from a neighbour, and decided to make applesauce for my horse (instead of buying it for him every week) because he needs it to take medicine. I did 4x the sugar and cinnamon for the amount of apples I had, and made an oopsie cooking!! I only cooked the apples in the water, 20 minutes was perfect. Then drained **most** of the water out, poured the sugar mixture in and OMG it turned out perfectly. I've never made applesauce before,  and I barely cook! Super easy and lots of room for mistakes or adding your own ideas!

text:
Basic home style applesauce like I learned to make from my mother. Suggestions I would add would be to add half the sugar taste the applesauce after the apples were softened by cooking and adjust to personal taste. I use cinnamon stick instead of ground cinnamon so you don't end up with brown applesauce, again personal preference. For 4 to 5 apples I find half a stick  gives the hint of cinnamon we like.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4999256.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used this recipe as a guide.  I used 8 cups of apples (~10 apples), 1 2/3 C of water, substituted the sugar for 1/4 cup of honey, 1/2 T of cinnamon (we like cinnamon), 1/2 teaspoon of ginger, and 1/2 teaspoon of nutmeg.  Cooked over medium heat for about 15-18 mins.  Mashed it right off of the stove.  Let cool for about 5 mins.  Has great consistency, a great cinnamon flavor.  Going to be great with the pork loin roast for dinner.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I started making applesauce years ago when my kids and I came home from apple picking with 40 pounds of apples, uh oh! Finding things to do with the apples, I found this recipe, I have to say, I've never made it as Sarah says, I've always felt it was too much water and way too much sugar. I'll fill my crock pot with apples (about 20), then add about 1/2 cup sugar and only about 12 ounces of water. You really don't need a lot of sugar or water to make it delicious. Cook it on high for 3-4 hours and you have applesauce for a party. Don't forget the cinnamon, that's my kids favorite part.

madeRecipesCount:
1480
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7503916.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I liked the taste and ease of making of this apple sauce so much, that I made it 2 days in row.
The apples I used were the sweet kind ( golden delicious and McIntosh) so I cut the sugar to 2 tablespoons and that was the right sweetness for my family.
The 1st time I made, I followed the advise of some reviewers and used less water than called for and that resulted in very thick apple sauce. The second time I used the exact amount of water and the consistency was just perfect for me.
I plan on making this quite often this Fall.
The one thing, I would recommend is to stay near the stove as this cooks because with the lid on, it gets foamy and  start to spillover. Removing the lid and stirring occasionally helps.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my "go-to" recipe for applesauce.  The only change I occasionally make is to use apple cider (NOT apple juice) in place of the water.  You could also add just a pinch of nutmeg if you like.  This applesauce is one of my most requested dishes any time of year, and I always make sure I have some in the freezer.  It makes chunky rather than smooth applesauce, and that is how we like it. Be sure you use apples that are recommended for sauce; otherwise, you will find that the apples will take an exceptionally long time to "cook down."  I like to use a combination of Golden Delicious, Honey Crisp, Macintosh, Cortland, Staymen Winesap, and Granny Smith; never use Red Delicious or any other apple labeled "mainly for eating."
Review:

6.10.17   OK, I have to admit I did make some changes.  I‚Äôve been making homemade applesauce FOREVER (so it seems), and I do in the microwave.  We‚Äôre not into sugar much these days, so I did cut the sugar way back (my apples were plenty sweet on their own), and we like our applesauce chunky, so I didn‚Äôt mash much.  The biggest change is that I cooked this in the microwave, covered, on high for 5 minutes...boom, done!  Honestly, I really don‚Äôt think you need a recipe for this, but if it helps some folks, so be it.  Ended up tasting good.
