text:
I've tried it as written, and it's good.  I also used Jules' tip with putting it in the slow cooker.  I find that the amounts of water and sugar needed depends on the type/ripeness of apple used.  I use firm gala apples, water and sugar as written (brown sugar works great), and sometimes add 1/2 tsp nutmeg.  Either cook it on the stove as written or follow Jules' directions and dump it all in the slow cooker and it comes out great!!!

text:
While I would definitely make this again, I would not use as much water. I ended up having to drain out a lot of the juice to get the consistency I wanted (much like the store brand). I also pulsed it in my blender using the food processor attachment. I used a whole bag of Fuji apples, which was the equivalent of tripling the recipe. After draining out all the juice, I added some back in, along with a little water, and the sweetness was perfect. My husband and one year old absolutely loved it! Can't wait to eat it chilled!

text:
I subbed in just shy of 1/4 cup of Organic Honey in place of the White Sugar.  In addition, I cooked in an Instant Pot, using Manual setting, High Pressure and cook time of 7 minutes.  For the Instant Pot, turn off immediately after cooking and let it naturally cool down.  If you try and vent the steam, it will spew out apple sauce!

text:
This is really good... with a couple of caveats. First, I used six small apples. I used the recommended amounts of water and sugar, and otherwise followed the instructions. It came out REALLY sweet. Don't get me wrong- it was good. But husband and I found it way too sweet to snack on, and ended up serving it warm, over nonfat vanilla frozen yogurt. REALLY good that way. If I were to make this again, especially to eat in a non-dessert way, I'd cut down on the sugar or even eliminate it completely. As a dessert topping, though, very good as-is.

text:
my family can't get enough of this applesauce.  I now make it several times in the fall, and quadruple the recipe or more.  I also make it in the crock pot.  When quadrupling, I do not increase the water at all.  I also cut down on the sugar  per each time I double the recipe (so if making 8  apples, might only add 2/3 C sugar, might not go much over 1C for a quadrupled batch (my apple trees are red and yellow delicious so they are pretty sweet to being with so I've been trying to see how little sugar is the right amount).  And for personal preference, I use brown sugar instead of white.

text:
I made a double recipe using granny smith apples and 1 honey crisp apple.  Allowed it to boil for about 10 minutes then let it simmer until the apples were soft.  I lightly mashed it so the apple sauce was chunky then simmered for another until a bit longer.  Perfect!  My husband likes it cold and raved about it.  It is great warm too.

This turned out just fanTAStic.  Although I hate it when people change the recipes......I changed the recipe.  I simply used a bit less water (1/4 cup per batch instead of 3/4) and honey instead of the sugar. Our apples were fresh off the tree though, and very juicy.  And I just find the sweetness from honey is "softer" somehow than granular sugar.  Regardless, this is a super simple, delicious recipe even I didn't screw up!!

I have used this recipe several times.  I do not peel the apples and I use Agave (Amber or Blue) instead of white sugar.  Be careful when using Agave , it is sweeter than white sugar (2/3 C of Agave = 1 C of sugar).  Consistently good!

I made this with some apples I froze a couple months ago. I partially defrosted two gallon size bags of sliced/cored apples, added 1 cup of water, 1 tsp. cinnamon, 1/2 cup of sugar, and a splash of lemon juice. After cooking it on the stove for 20 min. I let it cool and then blended it with my blender. It turned out great!

text:
I have already made this four times, each a different amount. Six apples, eight apples, anything! The one problem I have is the water. Please note, if you use very juicy apples you almost need no water at all! If you use dryer ones, use the amount listed. Honestly, I think that the water listed a little too much. Mashing the apples takes time too, so I advise using a tool,  or just cooking it longer. Either way, this applesauce was very good!

userID:
3829374
Display Name:
MEA

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Geeat recipe, as this is my second time ever making applesauce.  I used a crockpot as suggested, and tripled the recipe.  I used 2 cups of water, cut the cinnamon in half because I didn't want my applesauce dark brown.  I used both white and brown sugar, with a small squeeze of lemon juice.  I also used 2 drops of vanilla extract, and 1 drop of lemon extract.  What you must do is an hour into the cooking time, stir the apples and check the liquid content.  If your apples seem to be swimming in liquid, POOR some into a container (it is great apple juice/cider!)  Continue cooking, while checking and stirring frequently.  As the apples produce more and more liquid, continue to poor it in the container.  I preferably don't like soupy applesauce, that's why pouring the juice off is important.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I always make big batches of this recipe  but i add a little more cinnamon for more of a kick. When  i chop the apples up i always make sure that they are thinly chopped since it helps make it less chunky in the end, when it is done boiling i allow for a few minutes to cool down. I always tend to use a little hand mixer to smooth out the chunks  instead of mashing it with a fork or a potato masher, it saves on time and it comes out with a better result. Ive tried this recipe at least 4 times, first following it to a T but my family just likes it more smooth and some more cinnamon but this is defiantly a keeper

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Well, I have an abundance of apples here-  all different kinds- Transparents, Macs, Jonnies, and Northern Spy.  I was canning applesauce, and decided to mix this variety, and multiplied the recipe x10.   Because some of the apple were more juicy than others, I used only 6c of water; sugar ended up needing only 3 c.  I used raw sugar.   The Spy is a very hard apple, and doesn't mash easily. So, I took the emulsion blender to it.  I left a few chunks, and it was fabulous!  My son absolutely LOVED it. So did DH, and all the other kids. So, its a keeper!  I will be on my third batch tomorrow, for canning. =)  Just keep in mind, that the amount of sugar and water will be largely dependent on what type of apples you use.

Had a bunch of apples that needed to be used up.  Used 12 apples - peeled, sliced and put in the slow cooker.  1/2 cup sugar, 1 full tsp of cinnamon and 1 cup water.  On high for 3 hours. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I always want something sweet along with eating chicken and I didn't have anything, was out of applesauce.  I found some apples that were drying up a bit in the fridge and made this recipe.  I read the reviews about it being too sweet and too much water after I had put the apples on to cook.  Easy remedy, I drained the water off and mashed the apples with a fork and then whisked them a little.  I left out the cinnamon because I like applesauce plain.  Its GOOD ENOUGH with no additives!  It was wonderful, loved it!   The apples were red delicious apples and I'm sure the sugar in the water sweetened them up a bit, even though it was drained before mashing.  I will DEFINATELY make this again.  What a wonderful way to use up apples that aren't so great to eat, but are wonderful when sauced!

Turned out yummy but Four stars because I did not need nearly that much water - just put in a bit, probably about a 1/4 cup - and I used 9 ginger gold apples. photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just tried it. I have a unique apple tree, 4-antique varieties grafted onto one tree. Almost every year the apples do not make it to September due to squirrels and ground hogs. This year is different. Five pounds of apples made 3-plus quarts of apple sauce. Juice and peel of half a lemon and sweetened with 1/2 cup each of brown and white sugar and 8 packets of Equal. Delicious! More apples on the tree so come on over! Apple sauce from Pop-Pop for grandson Eli, age 3.

text:
I doubled this recipe and am quite dissapointed! Way too much cinnamon, way too much water (my applesauce is runny!) and I am glad I went with my instincts and didn't add any sugar. Way too much sugar in this recipe too. If I were to make this again,I would half the water and do a 1/3 of the cinnamon. Now i have a pot of applesauce that is almost unedible due to the amount of cinnamon in it!

country:
None
text:
We really liked this! Cut back a little bit on the cinnamon and added a sprinkle of nutmeg. Very good! The apples that I used were HUGE Gala apples, so the amount of water and sugar were spot on, but I think for smaller apples I would cut back quite a bit. Made this late at night, so I didn't use the blender since that would wake everyone up. Just cooked for about 10 minutes longer so the apples were really falling apart and mashed with a potato masher. Can't wait to try this again with different varieties of apples!

text:
This is my go to applesauce recipe!  I prefer to make it raw though. I keep all of the ingredients the same except that I put them all in a powerful blender, like a VitaMix or Blendtec blender. I also leave the skin on for added nutrition and ease. Tastes absolutely wonderful! When we want to add a flavor I just add a 1/2 cup of which ever fresh or frozen fruit that I have on hand. So far have tried, Blueberry, Cranberry, Peach, Mango, and Strawberry. All have been terrific!

None
text:
I love this recipe. I use a combination of Granny Smith's and Red and Golden Delicious and leave out the sugar. There is enough sweetness in the 'delicious' apples to compensate for the sugar for me. I leave out the cinnamon, place in canning jars and process in a boiling bath for 10 minutes to seal. When I an ready to use, I add the cinnamon while it is heating for those of us who like cinnamon and I also throw in some chopped walnuts for added flavor. Yummy!

text:
This was good but too sweet for me as written. Very easy to put together and totally worth it to have fresh applesauce. Great way to use up apples as well. I liked it a lot more the second time I made it. That time, I used brown sugar instead of white, less cinnamon, and apple cider instead of water. This is one of those recipes where I think it's really necessary to tweak for your personal preferences. Thank you for a great starting point!

Display Name:
LUCKY

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677177.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love making applesauce, I like using a soft apple that will cook down quickly. I wash the apples then quarter them and put them in a large pot with a small amount of water/applejuice. Boil until soft. Mash with a potato masher and strain through a sive. The sauce will have a nice pinky appearance. Add dash of cinnamon & nutmeg and that is it. I have also added pomengrates to the apples while cooking. Very flavourable. You do not have to add sugar - the apples have alot of natural sugar.

text:
I thought applesauce only came in jars from the store till I discovered your recipe and made applesauce for the first time.  Quick, easy and best of all, delicious.  Used two Golden Delicious and two Fuji apples.  Left out cinnamon as I wanted a pure apple taste.  Result was a refreshing applesauce that blended the flavor of both types of apples nicely.  Fuji apples kept its shape after cooking but was tender to mash with a fork for a textured applesauce which I like.  I'm hooked on making my own applesauce now.  Thank you for sharing this duck's guts (Aussie expression for awesome) recipe.

country:

text:
I've made this twice now, both times in the slow cooker.  REALLY REALLY GOOD!!  Considering there's barely any work involved (short of peeling the apples and mixing a few ingredients), so well worth making vs. buying!!!  First time, made it as written - entire family LOVED it (including 4 kids not always appreciative of my efforts).  Second time, tried others' suggestions of using brown sugar instead of white and a bit of nutmeg.  Still LOVED it!!!  The only word of warning (and to NO FAULT of the recipe), watch the kind of apples you use.  The second time I made it, I used apples that were squirting me as I was peeling them and I thought, hmmmm, I should cut back on the recommended water.....but I didn't.  When it was done, I did find it was a bit more watery but it still tasted great.  Just something to keep in mind.

text:
I just made this recipe.  I also think there is too much sugar in the recipe so I reduced to only about a 1/4 of a cup or less with about a dozen Spy apples peeled and cored and quartered.  I added only about a 1/4 cup of water as the apples produce liquid also.  I also added a cinnamon stick while simmering.  Sauce is delicious and can be mashed easily to make a smoother sauce if desired. I didn't give a 5 star either because of the excessive amount of sugar and water as called for in the original recipe.  You can always add sugar after taste testing.

userID:
2190453
Display Name:
Matt
isPro:

followersCount:

2
favoritesCount:
4
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Some important details:  Apple variety and quality is key.  I use Breaburns as they have a good balance of flavor, sweetness, and tartness.  Often times your grocer will let you taste one of the apples and will cut a slice for you right there.  Don't slice the apples too thin, leave them in big chunks.  Thin slices tend to not break down as easily.  Sugar to taste after the apples have cooked down.  I make my own applesauce just to avoid sugar.  If you like sweeter applesauce, replace the water with apple juice.  I often times add brandy, bourbon, and/or rum in the beginning.  The alcohol cooks off and it adds a little sweetness and flavor.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2010-04-18T10:17:36.273

text:
I got suckered in by a great sale and bought way too many Spartans so I've made this twice this week.  The first time I made it according to the recipe and found it very sweet, more like apple pie filling.  The second time I cut the sugar down to 1 tbsp and it's much more 'applesauce-y'.  So if you're using a sweet apple you don't need to add so much sugar.  But it's great!

text:
it's super delicious, but anything that sweet usually tastes pretty super. I used 5 small McIntosh apples and it came out good, but waaaayyy too sweet. Next time I will halve the sugar. Also, at medium heat, the sauce kept boiling over with the lid on. Even when I put the lid on half-way, it still boiled over. I had to reduce the heat quite a bit for the last 7 minutes so when the 15 minutes were up, i turned off the stove but left the sauce to continue heating in the pot.

region:

country:
None
text:
Wonderful recipe! I followed the recipe pretty much - I used 4 decent sized Jonagold apples. I diced them, added slightly less sugar than required, a tad more cinnamon and same amount of water. At first I thought it was going to be too liquidy when stirring it after it started cooking, but it wasn't. The liquid  "dried up" nicely. I have small kids and texture is a big thing so I put it in my Magic Bullet for a few pulses and it was just wonderful! 4 apples do cook down to not nearly enough sauce... I could easily polish off that bowl all by myself. I will definitely be making this again. Super yummy and fairly healthy as well. When I do make more, I will be using less sugar.

text:
I made this and found it a great alternative to buying the little cups in the grocery store.  However, being diabetic, I decided to re-run the nutritional data (I used 5 apples, since that's what I had).  When I ran the data, I got 48.5g of carbs per serving (my yield was 6 6oz servings).  Not sure what serving size they estimated, since they didn't include this data, but if they meant 4 oz, the carbs listed are about right - however, you should get more like 6 or 7 servings at that size.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My husband loves applesauce of any kind...well not exactly... it was always something i could never remember when i got to the grocery store.  Then I found this recipe and at the same time Costco had a dozen apples for some ridiculous price...Cameos, I think...so I bought them and came home and made a double batch, using the crock pot method suggested on this site.  I did as they said...less water, less sugar, as these apples were very sweet, and cooked for about 4 hours.  The last half hour i take the lid off to reduce the liquid and smashed the apples with the back of a spoon.  I also add some cinnamon, as we like that.  Eveyone i have served this to, including my sister who is a fabulous cook LOVES it.  In fact, she asked to have it twice when she was visiting this winter. If you like applesauce you will never buy another jar of it again with this recipe.

text:
Good recipe, but make sure you PEEL the apples!  Apple peels have a lot of insoluble fiber, which doesn't break down easily.  The inner part of the apple has a lot of soluble fiber which creates the gel consistency of applesauce.

text:
I never made applesauce before but this is great.  After reading reviews I used my crock pot and cooked it for 4 hours on high.  I used 2 Cortland and 2 Granny Smith apples.  I split the liquid to 1/4 cup cider and 1/2 cup water.  I also split the sugar to 1/8 cup each white and light brown sugar.  And finally I added the juice of 1/2 a lemon.  I'm lucky I got any into the fridge to cool 'cause my husband kept eating it hot.

text:
This turned out great.  Always nice to have a simple recipe with simple ingredients to let what nature intended shine.  I used Rome apples, which are similar to Granny Smiths.  I thought it was great how it was, but if you're looking to cut back on your sugar intake (or if you're making this for young kids), I think it would be fine with less sugar.  It is definitely a cinnamon apple sauce.  If you're looking for regular apple sauce, omit the cinnamon.

helpfulCount:
0
userID:
464048
Display Name:
MargieB
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
34
favoritesCount:
337
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Applesauce can be substituted in so many recipes for butter or oil, it only makes sense to make your own. This also can be made easily in the microwave in a covered micro safe dish. I peel my apples and then grate them from the whole apple till I get to the core. I don't add any water if the apples are very juicy and check for sweetness before adding any sugar. Cinnamon is a must for good flavor. Some apples don't lend themselves very well to applesauce because they don't break down very well. Haralson are such crisp apples, I have a hard time making applesauce using them. My favorite is Cortland, Macintosh, Granny Smith and Washington. Mix them up for a treat. Sometimes my Grandaughter only takes one bite out of an apple. I cut out the bite and put them in a ziplock bag and refrigerate until I get enough for some applesauce. No waste anymore... Thanks for posting such an easy recipe.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2008-11-05T21:00:02.44

I didn't know making applesauce was so easy!  I've made this twice in the last 3 days because I ate the 1st batch immediately.   The second time around I cut back the sugar because it was too sweet initially.  I prefer chunky style so I didn't bother mashing the apples up.

text:
I thought there was too much liquid for this recipe.  I used quite a bit more apples than this called for and not so much water.  I also usually don't add so much cinnamon just because I like the flavor of the cooked apples without it.  I think applesauce is pretty flexible to make adjustments so you can play around with this recipe a little bit to get the flavor that you prefer.  This recipe is good though, I just adjusted it to our taste.

text:
I don't like canned applesauce, but I've never attempted to make my own. Lately, however, I have been trying to make all my own food from scratch, and this recipe was amazing! I did, however, need to alter the recipe a bit. I used about 7 McIntosh apples, only enough water to cover the bottom of the pot, about 2 Tbsp. cinnamon, and only a few Tbsp. of sugar, tasting after each one. I only added the sugar after the apples had already become soft.
With the modifications....superb!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/125684.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is an awesome recipe, especially since I've been trying to cut all pre-packaged foods out of my diet! I used a mix of Gala and Granny Smith apples, and used brown sugar instead of white. Also, I don't put in the whole 1/4 Cup of sugar at once. I put in about half, then after I blend the applesauce in my food processor, I add more sugar to taste. I found my first batch was quite sweet, and this was the perfect way to sweeten it to my exact tastes.

Altogether, this is great and simple recipe!

text:
I made this and had the computer calculate it for 12 apples (12 servings) because that is how many apples are in a 3 lb. bag.  Used McAntosh which are slightly tart...but, I did the same as some of the other reviews and only used part of the sugar...I believe it called for 3/4 cup and I only added 1/2 cup.  I did add a bit more after tasting it when it was finished, probably 3 more tablespoons.  It tasted great as I like the sweetness.  I did not use as much cinnamon, just a couple of shakes.  I think this is a better way instead of following the recipe and potientally ruining the whole batch.  Had this for dinner and my daughter ate my bowl after finishing hers!!  Will definitely make again this fall!!

text:
I made 10 servings and followed the recipe exact.  At first I thought it was too much water because my apples were small that we picked at the apple farm  I cooked it for at least an hour because there was so much juice.  I tried to mash it but it wasn't mashing well enough so I poured batches in my bullet and blended. The consistancy was perfect, my 5 yr old and 1 yr old loved it.  They were my tasters.  It made 2 canning jars full.  Thanks!

text:
Next time I make this I'll have to remember to chop the apples smaller. I used 2 gala apples and 2 fugi apples that I cut into bite-sized pieces. I had to cook them longer than 20 minutes to get them soft enough to mash, so I lost some of the apple flavor which was dissapointing. I did sprinkle a little bit of ginger and nutmeg in the apples in addition to the cinnamon and sugar. I'll definitely make this applesauce again though.
